Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Primate stress and survival during a strong El Nino event

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Some studies have shown that high levels of stress hormones in animals are linked to lower reproductive success and survival ("fitness"). Other studies have found that higher stress hormone levels may be beneficial. In wild animal populations it is often hard to measure fitness and correct for other factors that affect hormone levels. This RAPID project will support immediate collection of stress and survival data for several capuchin monkey groups in Costa Rica. These monkeys are currently experiencing the environmental effects of a strong El Niño climate pattern. The opportunity to study a well-monitored monkey population during a stress event (El Niño) that affects all individuals is rare. The project will provide new data on how an individual's past and present hormone levels relate to their fitness. The researchers support graduate training of individuals from underrepresented groups in the STEM sciences. The project also includes science outreach activities in Costa Rica and the United States, and primate conservation efforts.

This project will test the cort-fitness hypothesis, which suggests that higher glucocorticoid hormone levels will be associated with reduced fitness. Currently, a very strong El Niño event is causing unprecedented mortality among a habituated, well-known population of white-faced capuchin monkeys (Cebus capucinus) at Lomas Barbudal in Costa Rica. This event presents the opportunity to test whether elevated glucocorticoids increase or decrease survival in wild capuchin monkeys subjected to a catastrophic stressor that affects all individuals. Longitudinal behavioral and fitness data and fecal measures of glucocorticoids will allow for an individual-level approach, correction for several other variables known to affect glucocorticoids in wild primates, consideration of past and present hormone levels for the same individual and in comparison with others, and assessment of infant mortality and maternal hormone levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

One of the most pervasive theoretical frameworks in behavioral endocrinology is the idea that individuals with high glucocorticoids should have reduced fitness compared to those individuals with low glucocorticoids. Although this hypothesis has been the primary guiding paradigm for research across biological disciplines, there are almost no data to support it. Few studies measure the link between glucocorticoids and fitness, and of the studies that do, the results remain inconclusive – possibly because much of the research has focused on the wrong comparisons. A proper test of this hypothesis should examine a singular and severe stressor that affects all individuals (somewhat) equally. Not surprisingly, such predictable opportunities are rare in wild populations.

 

From 2014-2015, the most severe El Niño on record caused unprecedented mortality among a habituated, well-known population of white-faced capuchin monkeys (Cebus capucinus) at Lomas Barbudal in Costa Rica. This NSF award allowed researchers to quickly increase the hormone sampling regime for this population of monkeys during this predictable, but catastrophic, challenge to address the question: when faced with a severe threat to survival, do elevated glucocorticoids increase or decrease survival for wild capuchin monkeys? Although we have not yet analyzed the data, the long-term project provides 12 years of hormonal, demographic, and detailed behavioral data on this population that will allow for an individual-level approach to this question using an unusually large sample size. After controlling for variables known to affect glucocorticoids in wild primates, this research will assess whether individual glucocorticoid levels during El Niño can predict survival. If individuals with higher glucocorticoids exhibit lower survival, then this supports the idea that elevated glucocorticoids hamper fitness, but if they exhibit higher survival, then this supports the idea that glucocorticoids are adaptive and can increase an animal’s fitness in response to a severe challenge. This research promises to be one of the few among mammalian studies (and the first among primate studies) to examine the fitness consequences of a severe environmental challenge in a wild population. Because each group of capuchins is simultaneously experiencing the same challenge, we are in a unique position to ascertain whether glucocorticoids increase or decrease the likelihood that capuchins are able to ‘weather the storm’.

 

Broader Impacts

The Lomas Barbudal Monkey Project continues its educational outreach projects in K-12 Costa Rican schools and adult communities adjacent to the field site. Training in field and/or lab methods was provided to 15 researchers, including 11 women, and 4 members of underrepresented ethnic groups; three of these women (including one Mexican) have already been admitted to graduate school in animal behavior on the strength of the experience received.

One exciting outcome from this research collaboration between Dr. Perry and Dr. Beehner was the fortuitous discovery (and subsequent establishment) of a new capuchin fieldsite at the Taboga Forest Reserve in Costa Rica. The Universidad Téchnica Nacional has offered us the use of the campus adjacent to the forest in exchange for our commitment to develop the site as a sustainable research station/field school where we can train students in field, laboratory, conservation, and sustainability methods. Together, we will build a one-of-a-kind, sustainable (“net zero”), international field station/training program, where we combine a diverse biological field site with an on-site environmental endocrinology laboratory and training facility for Costa Rican students/employees.
